issue.title: jekyll-last-modified-at plugin makes all posts to articles
issue.body:
I am using the jekyll-last-modified-at plugin. That automatically sets the date attribute based on the last changed date.

Unfortunately that turns all website content into og:type article (see line 46 in https://github.com/jekyll/jekyll-seo-tag/blob/master/lib/template.html).

That doesn't make any sense - and I can't even override it. Therefore I'd strongly recommend not to assume just because a page has a date that it's an article. Shat should be only set by hand if type is article.

issue.body:
Following the instructions at http://jekyllrb.com/docs/, I got to `gem install jekyll bundler`. It went on its merry way until it tried to install `ffi-1.15.5`. At that point it just kept creating new processes that look like:
```
16:56:58        00m04s         1000    27257    27253 pts/1    /bin/bash /home/matthew/gems/gems/ffi-1.15.5/ext/ffi_c/libffi/configure --disable-static --with-pic=yes --disable-dependency-tracking --disable-docs --host=
```
I was up to about 1200 of them when the laptop fans started really kicking in.
I am on Ubuntu on WSL2 on Windows 10:
```

Codename:       focal

ruby 2.7.0p0 (2019-12-25 revision 647ee6f091) [x86_64-linux-gnu]

Is there anything else I can provide in the way of diagnostics?

pull_request.title: Remove extra newline in css output
pull_request.body:
This PR removes an extra new line in the css output to make it fully consistent with dart-sass. Previously, a newline is explicitly added to make output compatible with sassc so that the same test case would pass for both implementations. Now the support for sassc is dropped, there is no need to keep that extra newline.

Although this is more of a cosmetic thing, it also has a small performance benefit of avoid copying the frozen string returned from protobuf when source map is disabled.

issue.title: [Docs]: Make the docs for all versions of Jekyll available for online browsing

labels.name: stale
labels.description: Nobody stepped up to work on this issue.

issue.body:
<!-- Thanks for taking the time to open an issue and help us make Jekyll better! -->

## Motivation

<!-- Why should we update our docs? -->

In response to @ashmaroli's [request on Jekyll-talk](https://talk.jekyllrb.com/t/core-feature-wishlist/7655), I suggested _versioned documentation_. I was already aware of the `jekyll-docs` gem, which supports *offline* browsing of various versions of the Jekyll docs. But when browsing on the web, it seems to me very odd that those versions of the docs aren’t available *online* too. 

@ashmaroli responded:

> To host a versioned docs at [jekyllrb.com](http://jekyllrb.com), we may need to move the source for [jekyllrb.com](http://jekyllrb.com) into a new repository. Please open an issue at the GitHub repository and ping `parkr` and `mattr-` for their take on the idea.
> 
> I meant the `jekyll/jekyll` repo actually. That’s where the source for docs at [jekyllrb.com](http://jekyllrb.com/) is located.

@parkr @mattr-: I'm now closing the corresponding issue on the `jekyll-docs` repo.

## Suggestion

<!-- What should we do instead? -->

I suggest to expand the Jekyll docs website to serve *all* the sites built by `jekyll-docs`. A menu on the main page should display the list of available versions, and support selection of a specific version.

However, you might also exploit the creation of a versioned docs website for Jekyll as a demonstration of how best to use Jekyll to build other versioned docs websites.[^1] The lack of direct Jekyll support for building versioned docs seems surprising on GitHub, where the focus is on version control! The [`versions-jekyll` ](https://github.com/justwriteclick/versions-jekyll) repo illustrates one way that developers might be able to set up versioned docs using Jekyll; perhaps provision of default GitHub Actions for use in theme templates could simplify that approach?

Various themes in other ecosystems *do* support versioned docs directly. The [answer ](https://talk.jekyllrb.com/t/versioned-documentation/6259/3) to a relatively recent [request for help ](https://talk.jekyllrb.com/t/versioned-documentation/6259) about support for versioned docs was to migrate the website from the Jekyll-based *Just the Docs* theme to *Read the Docs*…

@ashmaroli responded:

> Currently, Jekyll simply takes one source of truth and builds an output out of it. So to build an doculibrary of multiple versions, you would need to maintain multiple versions of sources in different directories to get one mega Jekyll build run. I don’t see how it is difficult for users to use existing Jekyll functionality to set up a versioned-docs with a centralized GH Action.

It may not be so difficult (at least for developers with experience of creating GH Actions). But I think it involves quite a lot of design considerations, as well as robust implementation. For example:

1. Should the sources of different doc versions be directories, collections, or branches?
2. Can (and should) unchanged doc source files be shared between versions?
3. Should version labels be semantic or arbitrary?
4. How can search results (e.g., from `lunr.js`) be restricted in the browser to a range of versions?
5. Can the contents of a version be updated after it has been built/published/released?
6. Should a versioned docs repo always be related to some code repo, or can it be independent of other repos?
7. Should users without GH Actions expertise be able to convert an unversioned docs repo to be versioned?
8. Etc.

For the offline Jekyll docs, some of the above questions have obvious answers, and some are irrelevant. But if you were to design and implement _general_ support for using Jekyll to build online versioned docs, the versioned Jekyll docs might be simply an (exemplary!) instance of it. And we might avoid Jekyll theme developers[^2] needing to design and implement their own variants of versioned docs.

[^1]: I realise that this part of my suggestion is more like a vague feature request than a proper docs issue…

[^2]: I'm involved in the development of the [Just the Docs](https://just-the-docs.github.io/just-the-docs/) theme, and we'd like to make our theme docs versioned, as well as to [support versioning](https://github.com/just-the-docs/just-the-docs/issues/728) for our users.

<!-- Thanks for taking the time to open an issue and help us make Jekyll better! -->

pull_request.title: Omit importer dependencies in docs-site workflow
pull_request.body:
## Summary

Avoid installing importer dependencies and test-suite dependencies while building / deploying the documentation site.

## Background

While setting-up *Deploy Previews* (on `pull_request` events) for the docs-site via Netlify. the build-image there failed to install certain gems with native=extensions due to missing dependencies of the native-code compiler.

## Advantages

- Lesser number of gems to install.
- Using conditional block in the gemspec instead of a Bundler group in the Gemfile means dev-dependencies continue getting listed at the Rubygems.org page as is current behavior.

labels.description: Nobody stepped up to work on this issue.

issue.body:
Hey there! :wave:

I noticed that the constraint you have for liquid doesn't allow for the latest version to be used.

The constraint I found was `~> 4.0`, and the latest version available is `5.4.0`.

Can you look into updating that constraint so our users can use the latest and greatest version? Thanks! :revolving_hearts:

commits.message: Update history to reflect merge of #9185 [ci skip]

Optimize default front matter using `File.fnmatch?` (#9185)

Merge pull request 9185

pull_request.title: Optimize default front matter using `File.fnmatch?`
pull_request.body:
- This is a :zap: change.
- I've added tests.

## Summary

Instead of using `Dir.glob` to create a list of matching paths and testing *given relative_patch* against each list entry, use `File.fnmatch?` to directly test if *given relative path* matches configured `scope["path"]` with glob pattern sigil (`*`).

## Notes

- With this, there is no need for having *collections_dir* as part of the `scope["path"]`. But for backwards-compatibility, continue accepting `scope["path"]` with collections_dir and strip it away under the hood. *TODO: Deprecate this need in a subsequent pull request.*

issue.title: [Docs]: As written, https://jekyllrb.com/docs/installation/ubuntu/ does not work on Ubuntu 22.04

labels.name: stale
labels.description: Nobody stepped up to work on this issue.

issue.body:
I would expect that https://jekyllrb.com/docs/installation/ubuntu/ would cover at least current releases of Ubuntu.

No errors occur down to "gem install jekyll bundler" on that page, but an attempt to serve a simple site https://github.com/SomeoneElseOSM/switch2osm.github.io fails:

"bundle install" gives no obvious errors
"bundle exec jekyll build" gives a few warnings but no errors
"bundle exec jekyll serve --host 0.0.0.0" falls over in a heap:

    Configuration file: /home/ajtown/src/switch2osm.github.io/_config.yml
                Source: /home/ajtown/src/switch2osm.github.io
           Destination: /home/ajtown/src/switch2osm.github.io/_site
     Incremental build: disabled. Enable with --incremental
          Generating...
                        done in 4.501 seconds.
    jekyll 3.9.0 | Error:  no implicit conversion of Hash into Integer
    /home/ajtown/gems/gems/pathutil-0.16.2/lib/pathutil.rb:502:in `read': no implicit conversion of Hash i    nto Integer (TypeError)
            from /home/ajtown/gems/gems/pathutil-0.16.2/lib/pathutil.rb:502:in `read'
            from /home/ajtown/gems/gems/jekyll-3.9.0/lib/jekyll/utils/platforms.rb:75:in `proc_version'
            from /home/ajtown/gems/gems/jekyll-3.9.0/lib/jekyll/utils/platforms.rb:40:in `bash_on_windows?    '

            from /home/ajtown/gems/gems/jekyll-3.9.0/lib/jekyll/commands/serve.rb:93:in `block in start'
            from /home/ajtown/gems/gems/jekyll-3.9.0/lib/jekyll/commands/serve.rb:93:in `each'
            from /home/ajtown/gems/gems/jekyll-3.9.0/lib/jekyll/commands/serve.rb:93:in `start'
            from /home/ajtown/gems/gems/jekyll-3.9.0/lib/jekyll/commands/serve.rb:75:in `block (2 levels)     in init_with_program'
            from /home/ajtown/gems/gems/mercenary-0.3.6/lib/mercenary/command.rb:220:in `block in execute'
            from /home/ajtown/gems/gems/mercenary-0.3.6/lib/mercenary/command.rb:220:in `each'

pull_request.title: Bump actions/checkout from 2 to 3
pull_request.body:
Bumps [actions/checkout](https://github.com/actions/checkout) from 2 to 3.
Release notes

Sourced from actions/checkout's releases.

v3.0.0

  • Updated to the node16 runtime by default
    • This requires a minimum Actions Runner version of v2.285.0 to run, which is by default available in GHES 3.4 or later.

v2.5.0

What's Changed

  • Update @​actions/core to 1.10.0 by @​rentziass in actions/checkout#962

Full Changelog: https://github.com/actions/checkout/compare/v2...v2.5.0

v2.4.2

What's Changed

  • Add set-safe-directory input to allow customers to take control. (#770) by @​TingluoHuang in actions/checkout#776
  • Prepare changelog for v2.4.2. by @​TingluoHuang in actions/checkout#778

Full Changelog: https://github.com/actions/checkout/compare/v2...v2.4.2

v2.4.1

  • Fixed an issue where checkout failed to run in container jobs due to the new git setting safe.directory

v2.4.0

  • Convert SSH URLs like org-<ORG_ID>@github.com: to https://github.com/ - pr

v2.3.5

Update dependencies

v2.3.4

  • Add missing awaits
  • Swap to Environment Files

v2.3.3

  • Remove Unneeded commit information from build logs
  • Add Licensed to verify third party dependencies

v2.3.2

Add Third Party License Information to Dist Files

v2.3.1

Fix default branch resolution for .wiki and when using SSH

v2.3.0

Fallback to the default branch

v2.2.0

Fetch all history for all tags and branches when fetch-depth=0

v2.1.1

Changes to support GHES (here and here)

... (truncated)

Changelog

Sourced from actions/checkout's changelog.

Changelog

v3.1.0

  • Use @​actions/core saveState and getState
  • Add github-server-url input

v3.0.2

  • Add input set-safe-directory

v3.0.1

  • Fixed an issue where checkout failed to run in container jobs due to the new git setting safe.directory
  • Bumped various npm package versions

v3.0.0

  • Update to node 16

v2.3.1

  • Fix default branch resolution for .wiki and when using SSH

v2.3.0

  • Fallback to the default branch

v2.2.0

  • Fetch all history for all tags and branches when fetch-depth=0

v2.1.1

  • Changes to support GHES (here and here)

v2.1.0

  • Group output
  • Changes to support GHES alpha release
  • Persist core.sshCommand for submodules
  • Add support ssh
  • Convert submodule SSH URL to HTTPS, when not using SSH
  • Add submodule support
  • Follow proxy settings
  • Fix ref for pr closed event when a pr is merged
  • Fix issue checking detached when git less than 2.22

v2.0.0

  • Do not pass cred on command line
  • Add input persist-credentials
  • Fallback to REST API to download repo

Installation to complete successfully.

For common failure modes I'd expect it to automatically handle them. issue.title: Use subtitle frontmatter variable if it exists
issue.body:
Hi,

if I am not mistaken, the variable `subtitle` (of specific posts) gets ignored currently. However I think it is quite commonly used and thus it would be nice if the subtitle of a post would show up in the RSS feed, if its exists.

An example; I am also using my RSS feed to generate Medium posts, and Zapier with Medium explicitly allows setting of a subtitle via RSS - I am currently cheesing this by misusing the description tag.

I would be happy to work on this request but I wanted to ask whether I am missing anything which would make this feature a bad idea ;)

pull_request.title: Generate social iconsheet during build
pull_request.body:
## Summary

Simplify management and maintainability of social media icons by using multiple *include files* and individual SVG files.

## Benefits / Advantages

- Users get the ability to change the order of rendered links.
- Users get the option to render multiple links to profiles on same platform.
- Users get the option to use a different icon for a given platform.
- Users get the option to easily alter link-rendering markup.
- Theme maintainers have lower overhead over deciding to bundle each and every requested social icon.

## Drawbacks / Disadvantages

- Users have to explicitly declare a more verbose configuration to render the list-item.
- Users *may* need to edit non-builtin icons to render correctly.
- The theme no longer *escapes* user-input. The onus is entirely on the user.

issue.title: feat: Enhance debug-level log output

labels.name: stale
labels.description: Nobody stepped up to work on this issue.

issue.body:
## Summary
Enhance debug-level log output so identifying problem Jekyll pages is easier. 

## Motivation
When log level `debug` is active, the following is output for every page:

```
Rendering: index.html
Pre-Render Hooks: index.html
Rendering Liquid: index.html
Rendering Markup: index.html
Post-Convert Hooks: index.html
Rendering Layout: index.html
```
When a file starts to be processed, its path should be output, then the rest of the information pertaining to that file should be indented, so it is apparent that it is all related.

Timing information per file should be shown, so pages that take a long time can be identified.

The time to perform each step for each page should be displayed, so steps that take a long time can be identified. Time intervals are much more useful than timestamps.

pull_request.title: Run tests in utc
pull_request.body:
- I read the contributing document at https://jekyllrb.com/docs/contributing/

This is a 🐛 bug fix.

- I've added tests (if it's a bug, feature or enhancement)
- I've adjusted the documentation (if it's a feature or enhancement)
- The test suite passes locally (run `script/cibuild` to verify this)

## Summary

If on a system where system timezone is not +00,
when tests are launched with 'script/test', test case
"TestFilters#test_: filters jsonify filter should convert drop to json"
fails due to difference in expected and actual value of 'date'.
This difference equals the system timezone offset.
Some other forms of lauching tests do work,
such as 'script/test test/test_filters.rb'.
    
Make the tests run correctly regardless of system timezone
by setting TZ=UTC.

## Context

Not related to a GitHub issue.

issue.title: jekyll-last-modified-at plugin makes all posts to articles
issue.body:
I am using the jekyll-last-modified-at plugin. That automatically sets the date attribute based on the last changed date.

Unfortunately that turns all website content into og:type article (see line 46 in https://github.com/jekyll/jekyll-seo-tag/blob/master/lib/template.html).

That doesn't make any sense - and I can't even override it. Therefore I'd strongly recommend not to assume just because a page has a date that it's an article. Shat should be only set by hand if type is article.

pull_request.title: Remove extra newline in css output
pull_request.body:
This PR removes an extra new line in the css output to make it fully consistent with dart-sass. Previously, a newline is explicitly added to make output compatible with sassc so that the same test case would pass for both implementations. Now the support for sassc is dropped, there is no need to keep that extra newline.

Although this is more of a cosmetic thing, it also has a small performance benefit of avoid copying the frozen string returned from protobuf when source map is disabled.

issue.title: [Docs]: Make the docs for all versions of Jekyll available for online browsing

labels.name: stale
labels.description: Nobody stepped up to work on this issue.

issue.body:
<!-- Thanks for taking the time to open an issue and help us make Jekyll better! -->

## Motivation

<!-- Why should we update our docs? -->

In response to @ashmaroli's [request on Jekyll-talk](https://talk.jekyllrb.com/t/core-feature-wishlist/7655), I suggested _versioned documentation_. I was already aware of the `jekyll-docs` gem, which supports *offline* browsing of various versions of the Jekyll docs. But when browsing on the web, it seems to me very odd that those versions of the docs aren’t available *online* too. 

@ashmaroli responded:

> To host a versioned docs at [jekyllrb.com](http://jekyllrb.com), we may need to move the source for [jekyllrb.com](http://jekyllrb.com) into a new repository. Please open an issue at the GitHub repository and ping `parkr` and `mattr-` for their take on the idea.
> 
> I meant the `jekyll/jekyll` repo actually. That’s where the source for docs at [jekyllrb.com](http://jekyllrb.com/) is located.

@parkr @mattr-: I'm now closing the corresponding issue on the `jekyll-docs` repo.

## Suggestion

<!-- What should we do instead? -->

I suggest to expand the Jekyll docs website to serve *all* the sites built by `jekyll-docs`. A menu on the main page should display the list of available versions, and support selection of a specific version.

However, you might also exploit the creation of a versioned docs website for Jekyll as a demonstration of how best to use Jekyll to build other versioned docs websites.[^1] The lack of direct Jekyll support for building versioned docs seems surprising on GitHub, where the focus is on version control! The [`versions-jekyll` ](https://github.com/justwriteclick/versions-jekyll) repo illustrates one way that developers might be able to set up versioned docs using Jekyll; perhaps provision of default GitHub Actions for use in theme templates could simplify that approach?

Various themes in other ecosystems *do* support versioned docs directly. The [answer ](https://talk.jekyllrb.com/t/versioned-documentation/6259/3) to a relatively recent [request for help ](https://talk.jekyllrb.com/t/versioned-documentation/6259) about support for versioned docs was to migrate the website from the Jekyll-based *Just the Docs* theme to *Read the Docs*…

@ashmaroli responded:

> Currently, Jekyll simply takes one source of truth and builds an output out of it. So to build an doculibrary of multiple versions, you would need to maintain multiple versions of sources in different directories to get one mega Jekyll build run. I don’t see how it is difficult for users to use existing Jekyll functionality to set up a versioned-docs with a centralized GH Action.

It may not be so difficult (at least for developers with experience of creating GH Actions). But I think it involves quite a lot of design considerations, as well as robust implementation. For example:

1. Should the sources of different doc versions be directories, collections, or branches?
2. Can (and should) unchanged doc source files be shared between versions?
3. Should version labels be semantic or arbitrary?
4. How can search results (e.g., from `lunr.js`) be restricted in the browser to a range of versions?
5. Can the contents of a version be updated after it has been built/published/released?
6. Should a versioned docs repo always be related to some code repo, or can it be independent of other repos?
7. Should users without GH Actions expertise be able to convert an unversioned docs repo to be versioned?
8. Etc.

For the offline Jekyll docs, some of the above questions have obvious answers, and some are irrelevant. But if you were to design and implement _general_ support for using Jekyll to build online versioned docs, the versioned Jekyll docs might be simply an (exemplary!) instance of it. And we might avoid Jekyll theme developers[^2] needing to design and implement their own variants of versioned docs.

[^1]: I realise that this part of my suggestion is more like a vague feature request than a proper docs issue…

[^2]: I'm involved in the development of the [Just the Docs](https://just-the-docs.github.io/just-the-docs/) theme, and we'd like to make our theme docs versioned, as well as to [support versioning](https://github.com/just-the-docs/just-the-docs/issues/728) for our users.

<!-- Thanks for taking the time to open an issue and help us make Jekyll better! -->

pull_request.title: Omit importer dependencies in docs-site workflow
pull_request.body:
## Summary

Avoid installing importer dependencies and test-suite dependencies while building / deploying the documentation site.

## Background

While setting-up *Deploy Previews* (on `pull_request` events) for the docs-site via Netlify. the build-image there failed to install certain gems with native=extensions due to missing dependencies of the native-code compiler.

## Advantages

- Lesser number of gems to install.
- Using conditional block in the gemspec instead of a Bundler group in the Gemfile means dev-dependencies continue getting listed at the Rubygems.org page as is current behavior.

labels.name: stale

issue.body:
### Operating System Rocky Linux 8.5 ### Ruby Version ruby 2.5.9p229 (2021-04-05 revision 67939) [x86_64-linux] ### Jekyll Version jekyll 4.2.2 ### GitHub Pages Version _No response_ ### Expected Behavior When a heading has a leading number in it, either auto-generated by [jekyll-numbered-headings](https://github.com/muratayusuke/jekyll-numbered-headings) or manually created, [Kramdown should strip the leading number](https://kramdown.gettalong.org/converter/html.html#auto-ids) before creating the `id` for the heading. For example: ```markdown ## 12. My Heading ``` Should render as (basically) ```html

12. My Heading

``` When I manually call `bundle exec kramdown -x kramdown-parser-gfm test_file.md` on my document, it generates the above expected `

`, so I don't think it's a problem with Kramdown? `bundle exec kramdown --version` gives `2.4.0`. ### Current Behavior This: ```markdown ## 12. My Heading ``` is rendered as: ```html

12. My Heading

``` ### Relevant log output _No response_ ### Code Sample ```markdown ## 12. My Heading ```

commits.message: Update history to reflect merge of #9185 [ci skip]

Optimize default front matter using `File.fnmatch?` (#9185)

Merge pull request 9185

pull_request.title: Optimize default front matter using `File.fnmatch?`
pull_request.body:
- This is a :zap: change.
- I've added tests.

## Summary

Instead of using `Dir.glob` to create a list of matching paths and testing *given relative_patch* against each list entry, use `File.fnmatch?` to directly test if *given relative path* matches configured `scope["path"]` with glob pattern sigil (`*`).

## Notes

- With this, there is no need for having *collections_dir* as part of the `scope["path"]`. But for backwards-compatibility, continue accepting `scope["path"]` with collections_dir and strip it away under the hood. *TODO: Deprecate this need in a subsequent pull request.*

labels.name: stale

issue.body:
### Operating System

Debian 11 Bullseye (amd64)

### Ruby Version

ruby 2.7.4p191 (2021-07-07 revision a21a3b7d23) [x86_64-linux-gnu]

### Jekyll Version

Fetching jekyll-4.2.2.gem

### GitHub Pages Version

Fetching bundler-2.3.21.gem

### Expected Behavior

Installation to complete successfully.

This is more of a heads-up for others hitting this stumbling block. Not a criticism but should be known.
 
For common failure modes I'd expect it to automatically handle them. In this example, from the hints in the log, it seems like it should specify OS package dependencies that may be needed in the docs (problem there being there are many places where minimalist instructions are displayed like the web-site front page!).

In this case it requires `apt install --no-install-recommends ruby-dev`

Generally I try to keep `-dev` packages off production systems because they have an annoying tendency to pull in everything including the kitchen sink (hence the `--no-install-recommends` above)!

Hi,

if I am not mistaken, the variable `subtitle` (of specific posts) gets ignored currently. However I think it is quite commonly used and thus it would be nice if the subtitle of a post would show up in the RSS feed, if its exists.

An example; I am also using my RSS feed to generate Medium posts, and Zapier with Medium explicitly allows setting of a subtitle via RSS - I am currently cheesing this by misusing the description tag.

I would be happy to work on this request but I wanted to ask whether I am missing anything which would make this feature a bad idea ;)

Merge pull request 686

pull_request.title: Generate social iconsheet during build
pull_request.body:
## Summary

Simplify management and maintainability of social media icons by using multiple *include files* and individual SVG files.

## Benefits / Advantages

- Users get the ability to change the order of rendered links.
- Users get the option to render multiple links to profiles on same platform.
- Users get the option to use a different icon for a given platform.
- Users get the option to easily alter link-rendering markup.
- Theme maintainers have lower overhead over deciding to bundle each and every requested social icon.

## Drawbacks / Disadvantages

- Users have to explicitly declare a more verbose configuration to render the list-item.
- Users *may* need to edit non-builtin icons to render correctly.
- The theme no longer *escapes* user-input. The onus is entirely on the user.

issue.title: feat: Enhance debug-level log output

labels.name: stale
labels.description: Nobody stepped up to work on this issue.

issue.body:
## Summary
Enhance debug-level log output so identifying problem Jekyll pages is easier. 

## Motivation
When log level `debug` is active, the following is output for every page:

```
Rendering: index.html
Pre-Render Hooks: index.html
Rendering Liquid: index.html
Rendering Markup: index.html
Post-Convert Hooks: index.html
Rendering Layout: index.html
```
When a file starts to be processed, its path should be output, then the rest of the information pertaining to that file should be indented, so it is apparent that it is all related.

Timing information per file should be shown, so pages that take a long time can be identified.

The time to perform each step for each page should be displayed, so steps that take a long time can be identified. Time intervals are much more useful than timestamps.

pull_request.title: Run tests in utc
pull_request.body:
- I read the contributing document at https://jekyllrb.com/docs/contributing/

This is a 🐛 bug fix.

- I've added tests (if it's a bug, feature or enhancement)
- I've adjusted the documentation (if it's a feature or enhancement)
- The test suite passes locally (run `script/cibuild` to verify this)

## Summary

If on a system where system timezone is not +00,
when tests are launched with 'script/test', test case
"TestFilters#test_: filters jsonify filter should convert drop to json"
fails due to difference in expected and actual value of 'date'.
This difference equals the system timezone offset.
Some other forms of lauching tests do work,
such as 'script/test test/test_filters.rb'.
    
Make the tests run correctly regardless of system timezone
by setting TZ=UTC.

## Context

Not related to a GitHub issue.

issue.title: jekyll-last-modified-at plugin makes all posts to articles
issue.body:
I am using the jekyll-last-modified-at plugin. That automatically sets the date attribute based on the last changed date.

Unfortunately that turns all website content into og:type article (see line 46 in https://github.com/jekyll/jekyll-seo-tag/blob/master/lib/template.html).

That doesn't make any sense - and I can't even override it. Therefore I'd strongly recommend not to assume just because a page has a date that it's an article. Shat should be only set by hand if type is article.

pull_request.title: Remove extra newline in css output
pull_request.body:
This PR removes an extra new line in the css output to make it fully consistent with dart-sass. Previously, a newline is explicitly added to make output compatible with sassc so that the same test case would pass for both implementations. Now the support for sassc is dropped, there is no need to keep that extra newline.

Although this is more of a cosmetic thing, it also has a small performance benefit of avoid copying the frozen string returned from protobuf when source map is disabled.

issue.title: [Docs]: Make the docs for all versions of Jekyll available for online browsing

labels.name: stale
labels.description: Nobody stepped up to work on this issue.

issue.body:
<!-- Thanks for taking the time to open an issue and help us make Jekyll better! -->

## Motivation

<!-- Why should we update our docs? -->

In response to @ashmaroli's [request on Jekyll-talk](https://talk.jekyllrb.com/t/core-feature-wishlist/7655), I suggested _versioned documentation_. I was already aware of the `jekyll-docs` gem, which supports *offline* browsing of various versions of the Jekyll docs. But when browsing on the web, it seems to me very odd that those versions of the docs aren’t available *online* too. 

@ashmaroli responded:

> To host a versioned docs at [jekyllrb.com](http://jekyllrb.com), we may need to move the source for [jekyllrb.com](http://jekyllrb.com) into a new repository. Please open an issue at the GitHub repository and ping `parkr` and `mattr-` for their take on the idea.
> 
> I meant the `jekyll/jekyll` repo actually. That’s where the source for docs at [jekyllrb.com](http://jekyllrb.com/) is located.

@parkr @mattr-: I'm now closing the corresponding issue on the `jekyll-docs` repo.

## Suggestion

<!-- What should we do instead? -->

I suggest to expand the Jekyll docs website to serve *all* the sites built by `jekyll-docs`. A menu on the main page should display the list of available versions, and support selection of a specific version.

However, you might also exploit the creation of a versioned docs website for Jekyll as a demonstration of how best to use Jekyll to build other versioned docs websites.[^1] The lack of direct Jekyll support for building versioned docs seems surprising on GitHub, where the focus is on version control! The [`versions-jekyll` ](https://github.com/justwriteclick/versions-jekyll) repo illustrates one way that developers might be able to set up versioned docs using Jekyll; perhaps provision of default GitHub Actions for use in theme templates could simplify that approach?

Various themes in other ecosystems *do* support versioned docs directly. The [answer ](https://talk.jekyllrb.com/t/versioned-documentation/6259/3) to a relatively recent [request for help ](https://talk.jekyllrb.com/t/versioned-documentation/6259) about support for versioned docs was to migrate the website from the Jekyll-based *Just the Docs* theme to *Read the Docs*…

@ashmaroli responded:

> Currently, Jekyll simply takes one source of truth and builds an output out of it. So to build an doculibrary of multiple versions, you would need to maintain multiple versions of sources in different directories to get one mega Jekyll build run. I don’t see how it is difficult for users to use existing Jekyll functionality to set up a versioned-docs with a centralized GH Action.

It may not be so difficult (at least for developers with experience of creating GH Actions). But I think it involves quite a lot of design considerations, as well as robust implementation. For example:

1. Should the sources of different doc versions be directories, collections, or branches?
2. Can (and should) unchanged doc source files be shared between versions?
3. Should version labels be semantic or arbitrary?
4. How can search results (e.g., from `lunr.js`) be restricted in the browser to a range of versions?
5. Can the contents of a version be updated after it has been built/published/released?
6. Should a versioned docs repo always be related to some code repo, or can it be independent of other repos?
7. Should users without GH Actions expertise be able to convert an unversioned docs repo to be versioned?
8. Etc.

For the offline Jekyll docs, some of the above questions have obvious answers, and some are irrelevant. But if you were to design and implement _general_ support for using Jekyll to build online versioned docs, the versioned Jekyll docs might be simply an (exemplary!) instance of it. And we might avoid Jekyll theme developers[^2] needing to design and implement their own variants of versioned docs.

[^1]: I realise that this part of my suggestion is more like a vague feature request than a proper docs issue…

[^2]: I'm involved in the development of the [Just the Docs](https://just-the-docs.github.io/just-the-docs/) theme, and we'd like to make our theme docs versioned, as well as to [support versioning](https://github.com/just-the-docs/just-the-docs/issues/728) for our users.

<!-- Thanks for taking the time to open an issue and help us make Jekyll better! -->

pull_request.title: Omit importer dependencies in docs-site workflow
pull_request.body:
## Summary

Avoid installing importer dependencies and test-suite dependencies while building / deploying the documentation site.

## Background

While setting-up *Deploy Previews* (on `pull_request` events) for the docs-site via Netlify. the build-image there failed to install certain gems with native=extensions due to missing dependencies of the native-code compiler.

## Advantages

- Lesser number of gems to install.
- Using conditional block in the gemspec instead of a Bundler group in the Gemfile means dev-dependencies continue getting listed at the Rubygems.org page as is current behavior.

Optimize default front matter using `File.fnmatch?` (#9185)

Merge pull request 9185

pull_request.title: Optimize default front matter using `File.fnmatch?`
pull_request.body:
- This is a :zap: change.
- I've added tests.

## Summary

Instead of using `Dir.glob` to create a list of matching paths and testing *given relative_patch* against each list entry, use `File.fnmatch?` to directly test if *given relative path* matches configured `scope["path"]` with glob pattern sigil (`*`).

## Notes

- With this, there is no need for having *collections_dir* as part of the `scope["path"]`. But for backwards-compatibility, continue accepting `scope["path"]` with collections_dir and strip it away under the hood. *TODO: Deprecate this need in a subsequent pull request.*

issue.body:
### Operating System

Debian 11 Bullseye (amd64)

### Ruby Version

ruby 2.7.4p191 (2021-07-07 revision a21a3b7d23) [x86_64-linux-gnu]

### Jekyll Version

Fetching jekyll-4.2.2.gem

### GitHub Pages Version

Fetching bundler-2.3.21.gem

### Expected Behavior

Installation to complete successfully.

This is more of a heads-up for others hitting this stumbling block. Not a criticism but should be known.
 
For common failure modes I'd expect it to automatically handle them. In this example, from the hints in the log, it seems like it should specify OS package dependencies that may be needed in the docs (problem there being there are many places where minimalist instructions are displayed like the web-site front page!).

In this case it requires `apt install --no-install-recommends ruby-dev`

Generally I try to keep `-dev` packages off production systems because they have an annoying tendency to pull in everything including the kitchen sink (hence the `--no-install-recommends` above)!

```

        ERROR: Failed to build gem native extension.

issue.title: Use subtitle frontmatter variable if it exists
issue.body:
Hi,

if I am not mistaken, the variable `subtitle` (of specific posts) gets ignored currently. However I think it is quite commonly used and thus it would be nice if the subtitle of a post would show up in the RSS feed, if its exists.

An example; I am also using my RSS feed to generate Medium posts, and Zapier with Medium explicitly allows setting of a subtitle via RSS - I am currently cheesing this by misusing the description tag.

I would be happy to work on this request but I wanted to ask whether I am missing anything which would make this feature a bad idea ;)

pull_request.title: Generate social iconsheet during build
pull_request.body:
## Summary

Simplify management and maintainability of social media icons by using multiple *include files* and individual SVG files.

## Benefits / Advantages

- Users get the ability to change the order of rendered links.
- Users get the option to render multiple links to profiles on same platform.
- Users get the option to use a different icon for a given platform.
- Users get the option to easily alter link-rendering markup.
- Theme maintainers have lower overhead over deciding to bundle each and every requested social icon.

## Drawbacks / Disadvantages

- Users have to explicitly declare a more verbose configuration to render the list-item.
- Users *may* need to edit non-builtin icons to render correctly.
- The theme no longer *escapes* user-input. The onus is entirely on the user.

issue.title: feat: Enhance debug-level log output

labels.name: stale
labels.description: Nobody stepped up to work on this issue.

issue.body:
## Summary
Enhance debug-level log output so identifying problem Jekyll pages is easier. 

## Motivation
When log level `debug` is active, the following is output for every page:

```
Rendering: index.html
Pre-Render Hooks: index.html
Rendering Liquid: index.html
Rendering Markup: index.html
Post-Convert Hooks: index.html
Rendering Layout: index.html
```
When a file starts to be processed, its path should be output, then the rest of the information pertaining to that file should be indented, so it is apparent that it is all related.

Timing information per file should be shown, so pages that take a long time can be identified.

The time to perform each step for each page should be displayed, so steps that take a long time can be identified. Time intervals are much more useful than timestamps.

If this is a **bug** and you can still reproduce this error on the latest 3.x-stable or master/main branch, please reply with all of the information you have about it in order to keep the issue open. If this is a **feature request**, please consider building it first as a plugin. Jekyll 3 introduced [hooks](http://jekyllrb.com/docs/plugins/#hooks) which provide convenient access points throughout the Jekyll build pipeline whereby most needs can be fulfilled. If this is something that cannot be built as a plugin, then please provide more information about why in order to keep this issue open. This issue will automatically be closed in two months if no further activity occurs. Thank you for all your contributions.

pull_request.title: Run tests in utc
pull_request.body:
- I read the contributing document at https://jekyllrb.com/docs/contributing/

This is a 🐛 bug fix.

- I've added tests (if it's a bug, feature or enhancement)
- I've adjusted the documentation (if it's a feature or enhancement)
- The test suite passes locally (run `script/cibuild` to verify this)

## Summary

If on a system where system timezone is not +00,
when tests are launched with 'script/test', test case
"TestFilters#test_: filters jsonify filter should convert drop to json"
fails due to difference in expected and actual value of 'date'.
This difference equals the system timezone offset.
Some other forms of lauching tests do work,
such as 'script/test test/test_filters.rb'.
    
Make the tests run correctly regardless of system timezone
by setting TZ=UTC.

## Context

Not related to a GitHub issue.
